top_comment.text: Is it a thing to refer to a country as 'her'?﻿
top_comment.author: Alexandre Hamada Possi

comments.text:
+Alexandre Hamada Possi It is a vestige of when the English language 
assigned gender to nouns, similar to how modern German treats its nouns. 
The English language got rid of most of the gender specific noun rules, 
English now refers to most nouns in the neuter, except for countries, 
animals and inanimate objects, which can be labeled as 'she' or 'her'. >> 
Ex. I got a Ford Mustang yesterday. Do you want to see her? She is a 
beauty. (The word 'IT' is also acceptable instead of she). 
I have noticed, that objects use 'she' if the object is seen as graceful or 
is somehow beautiful to the observer. This is my best interpretation of the 
use of 'she' or 'her' for objects. For countries, the use of "she" or 
"her".... (my interpretation) ....might be used because of an individual is 
willing to defend the country; the country being a place that raised the 
citizen thus the country is viewed as a mother or woman when looked at it 
in a traditionalist social family structure.
comments.author: Andrew Kelliher

comments.text: I just say "it" or "they."
comments.author: Anthony Serocco

comments.text:
Most people I know don't use feminine pronouns when referring to countries. 
Most people say "it", not "she". I've always thought the use of gendered 
pronouns when referring to inanimate objects is a bit strange.
comments.author: Penguin236

comments.text:
I'm by no means an expert on english etymology, much less on languages 
other than my own, but from the little I know it seems that most 
Latin-based (Romantic) languages seem to refer to to counties as feminine 
("sister countries", "Mother land", etc.) while I believe Germanic-based 
ones tend to refer to them in as masculine.  Each also tends to default to 
the same (masculine/ feminine) descriptors for other large institutions as 
they do with countries, such as Churches, legal establishments, businesses, 
or military branches.

I can only assume this is mostly a hold-over from before a non-gendered 
'it' entered so many languages, with each vein simply preserving the most 
popular/ historically entrenched 'gender' of an institution from it's root 
languages as a stylized informal way of referring to modern institutions...
comments.author: BoojumFed

comments.text:
There are many speculations as to why humans tend to refer objects as 
'she'. It might be considered, stylistically marked; an optional figure of 
speech. We know many times people tend to humanize things they love. But 
you'd notice that it isn't just countries that are referred as a 'she' or 
'her'; boats, cars, mechanical devices, some hurricanes. :D

I suppose (from a few sources on the internet), it is claimed that during 
the early days, ships were dedicated to some goddess. Other theories 
include that the crew thought that the ship 'cradled' them like a mother 
and this resulted in treating it with a great deal of respect. 
It's a tradition that got carried over.

Rarely and archaically, she referred to an immaterial thing without 
personification. Also of natural objects considered to be feminine, as the 
moon, or the planets that are named after goddesses; also of a river (now 
rare), formerly of the sea, a tree, etc. - wikipedia

Some see it that because the captains (usually male) are supposedly in love 
with the sea and their ship. A woman, their 'true love'. Hence, female 
pronouns. It's a supposed term of endearment. They call something a 'she' 
because they value it highly.
comments.author: indifference

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Alexandre Hamada Possi 'She' has often been used to describe countries and 
cities. It has also been used for armies and for institutions like the 
Church. It is quite often the convention that male gender is used when 
speaking of people in a gender neutral way (e.g "mankind", "a good student 
does his homework") but female gender is used as an alternative to 'it' 
when speaking of possessions or of abstractions like countries.

comments.text:
The interstate highways in Hawaii, more precisely on the island of Oahu, 
are all about money.  Oahu was in desperate need of some highways to move 
the traffic in and out of Honolulu--it has horrific traffic problems--so 
the locals and the state DOT came up with H-1, H-2 and H-3 to get the 
federal government to pay for almost all of it.  At the U.S. highway level, 
such as U.S. 1 and the old Route 66, the feds and the states shared the 
cost of those roads 50-50.  Anything lower on the pecking order such as 
county roads and city streets generally gets paid for at those levels; 
state roads get paid for by the state governments.  At the highest level, 
the interstates, the feds pick up 90% of the construction costs leaving the 
paltry 10% to the states.  So this is why there are interstate highways in 
Hawaii with their unique route prefixes so they aren't confused with 
mainland routes with the same numerals. +Phil Hopkins
comments.author: Leonard Goldstein

comments.text:
+Keenan Kelly Being born and having grown up in Montreal most of my life, I 
do see where you're coming from... It kinda saddens me a bit to know the 
image Quebec gets from the rest of Canada, even if I'm not "québécois" 
myself, as I'm of Latin-American parents. But really, only non-bilingual 
stubborn quebecers are going to be rude. If they don't speak english well 
enough (because trust me, most will understand it, in Montreal at least) 
and don't hold any resent or plain ignorance against anglophones, they'll 
just tell you they don't speak english or ignore you (which yeah, can seem 
quite impolite on the moment but, whatever right ?). You don't need to 
speak french to live here, even if it does help. But yeah I won't hide the 
fact that Quebec laws on language are pretty stupid and not only does it 
affect anglophones but also everyone here. For instance, sometimes you'll 
learn about some event or contest you want to attend/participate in, and 
you'll see it's happening in Canada & USA, so you're like "Ooh great !" and 
then you read more about it and you see it excludes Quebec... It only 
happened to me once but it pissed me off big time because you know it's 
because of some stupid and in the end, racist law. It really annoys me.

Recently I went to Kansas to visit some family and when I came back, I was 
amazed to see that once you enter the province, almost every sign of 
anything is french only... WTF ?!  Sure french is part of Quebec but still, 
we're in Canada, and what does that tell to american tourists ?  They 
shouldn't come here, thinking "Ooh, they speak french there but it's still 
Canada, everything's also going to be in english" and then actually come 
here and don't understand a thing, at least in the signs you see on the 
road or in some stores. I think either french should be a minor thing here, 
like in Galicia (Spain) for example, where yes, they speak Galician, but 
Spanish still dominates in pretty much everything), or Canada should just 
teach french more nationwide, but that's not an easy task and lots of 
people would most likely be against it. There's that too, the fact that the 
rest of Canada just ditches french because of Quebec. I love knowing french 
only because it opens all doors to french (from the actual France) culture, 
which is awesome. I really don't like Quebec culture, but that's just me. 
However, when it comes to France culture, it's great. I'm not a fanatic of 
anything, it's not my favorite culture, but I love french cinema, I love 
knowing that I can just go to France and just kick it, and other canadians 
should embrace the fact that they have the possibility of becoming 
bilingual, but it definitely shouldn't ever be imposed to anyone.

Just know that these stupid laws and whatnot affect us more than anybody 
else and that not everyone here is a stubborn Quebec/french fanatic (heck, 
Montreal's so diverse anyway that here, Quebecers are almost a minority).

comments.text:
Most Canadians outside of Quebec speak English as their fist language and 
learn French in grade 4. We do have Provinces but we also have 3 
Territories. Our money is not all green. $5s are blue, $10s are purple, 
$20s are green, $50s are red, and $100s are brown. It makes it easier to 
see what kind of bill it is before pulling it out of your wallet. Instead 
of $1 bills we have Loonies ($1 coin) and Toonies ($2 coin)

We have a Democracy but we don't have a President, we have a Prime Minster 
(Steven Harper). The main difference is that Prime Ministers have a bunch 
of other ministers that focus on parts running of Canada like Finance or 
saving the environment. The Prime Minister is the boss. Also Canada has had 
a women Prime Minister but America has never had a women President.

Canadians in general seem to be more polite. But Americans seem more 
friendly. Canadians also tend to be introverts and Americans, extroverts. 
Canadians do say "Eh?" but no more then Americans say "Right?" (Cool, eh? 
means: Cool, right? Saying aboot is a myth. About is about. Aboot is when 
you forget the space bar in "A boot". "Z" is Zed not Zee, but it's the 
original pronunciation. Americans changed it to rhyme with "V".

comments.text:
We actually have a pretty interesting history here in Canada. Albeit, not 
quite as fun or interesting as the US (Canadian history buffs are spitting 
their collective Tim Horton's coffees out right about now).

Quick answers to the topics you brought up, Canada has two official 
languages: English and French. French is generally spoken only in Quebec, 
but there are large francophone populations in Ontario, Alberta and lower 
Manitoba. Everywhere else speaks English. As for democracy, we can turn to 
Wikipedia, "Canada is a federal parliamentary democracy and a 
constitutional monarchy, with Queen Elizabeth II as its head of state." 
While the Queen may be the head of our state on paper, our Prime Minister 
(think President) and the other Members of Parliament hold the real power 
(similar in some respects to the UK).

We also have a long and incredibly complex history with the US that I 
encourage you to check out.

comments.text:
Here are the actual document that you can use to come into Canada and go 
Back to the States afterward.

Adults Travelling By Land or By Sea
U.S. Passport (or)
NEXUS or FAST card (pre-approved low risk travellers only) (or)
U.S. Passport Card (or)
Enhanced driver's licence (EDL) (available in MI, NY, WA; also proposed in 
AZ, CA, TX)

So NO, the Passport is not necessary as long as you have one of the other 
document.

http://www.tripadvisor.ca/Travel-g153339-s602/Canada:Crossing.The.Border.html

On the other hand if you are Canadian and are going to the states by Land.

Adult with Canadian Citizenship 
Canadian Passport (or)
Enhanced Driver's Licence/ID (EDL) (available in BC, MB, ON, QC; also 
proposed in NS) (or)
NEXUS/FAST card (pre-approved low-risk travelers only) (or)
Secure Certificate of Indian Status (subject to U.S. government approval)

http://www.tripadvisor.ca/Travel-g191-s602/United-States:Crossing.The.Border.html

People should really do their due research before posting things as if true.

If you were to be coming into Canada or the states on some small road that 
didn't have border checkup and was later called up, they would simply take 
a look at your valid document, make a quick search if you were not black 
listed, and then let you go on your merry way. And may or may not face a 
5000$ fine.

USA where things were laid out on a grid when people first settled <200 
years ago. It's odd having roads cut through ponds willy-nilly, but we 
always know what direction we're heading. Where my husband is from is older 
and nothing runs straight. I lost my sense of direction, which I thought 
was excellent, in just a mile or so. It's modern people who want things 
straight, I think. :-)

comments.text:
By British standards that is an extremely straight border. Look at a UK 
county map, or any local map of parish boundaries, and there are no 
straight lines. Borders follow ditches, hedgerows, and for all I know 
hedgehog territorial limits. Even today in the paper there was an argument 
whether Monmouthshire properly belonged to England or Wales, with people 
quoting various sixteenth century documents. It will probably never be 
resolved, but nobody cares.

comments.text:
We don't have a president, we have a parliamentary system like the UK. 
During federal elections we don't vote directly for the Prime Minister but 
rather the local Members of Parliament who represent many districts across 
Canada in parliament. For example, the MP in my area represents the 
Windsor-Tecumseh region in Ontario and is a member of the NDP (New 
Democratic Party). As well, we also have 3 major parties in our country who 
closely compete in the polls: NDP, Liberal Party and Conservative (Tory) 
Party. The Prime Minister is the appointed leader of whichever party wins 
the most seats in parliament (has the most MP representation). Right now 
the Conservative Party have the most MPs in parliament and there leader 
(and our current Prime Minister) is Stephen Harper. It's a system that is a 
lot less generalized where you vote for who you think will represent your 
municipal area best and why many think that it's a better system than the 
US. In my area of Windsor-Tecumseh we have consistently been represented by 
the NDP party which is the furthest left party in Canada. This is because 
they back up unions and our town is highly unionized with a Chrysler and 
Ford plant as well as a Ceasers Casino.

captions.text:
Canada and the United States share the longest,
straightest, possibly boringest border in

the world. But, look closer, and there's plenty
of bizarreness to be found.

While these sister nations get along fairly
well, they both want to make it really clear

whose side of the continent is whose. And
they've done this by carving a 20-foot wide

space along the border. All five and a half
thousand miles of it.

With the exception of the rare New England
town that predates national borders or the

odd airport that needed extending, this space
is the no-touching-zone between the countries

and they're super serious about keeping it
clear. It matters not if the no-touching-zone

runs through hundreds of miles of virtually
uninhabited Alaskan / Yukon wilderness. Those
border trees, will not stand.

Which might make you think this must be the
longest, straightest deforested place in the

world, but it isn't. Deforested: yes, but
straight? Not at all.

Sure it looks straight and on a map, and the
treaties establishing the line *say* it's

straight... but in the real world the official
border is 900 lines that zig-zags from the
horizontal by as much as several hundred feet.

How did this happen? Well, imagine you're
back in North America in the 1800s -- The

49th parallel (one of those horizontal lines
you see on a globe) has just been set as the

national boundary and it's your job to make
it real. You're handed a compass and a ball

of string and told to carefully mark off the
next 2/3rds of a continent. Don't mind that

uncharted wilderness in the way: just keep
the line straight.
Yeah.
Good luck.
With that.

The men who surveyed the land did the best
they could and built over 900 monuments. They're

in about as straight as you could expect a
pre-GPS civilization to make, but it's not

the kind of spherical / planar intersection
that would bring a mathematician joy.

Nonetheless these monuments define the border
and the no-touching-zone plays connect-the-dots
with them.

Oh, and while there are about 900 markers
along this section of the border, there are

about 8,000 in total that define the shape
of the nations.

Despite this massive project Canada and the
United States still have disputed territory.

There is a series of islands in the Atlantic
that the United States claims are part of

Maine and Canada claims are part of New Brunswick.
Canada, assuming the islands are hers built

a lighthouse on one of them, and the United
States, assuming the islands are hers pretends
the lighthouse doesn't exist.

It's not a huge problem as the argument is
mostly over tourists who want to see puffins

and fishermen who want to catch lobsters,
but let's hope the disagreement gets resolved
before someone finds oil under that lighthouse.

Even the non-disputed territory has a few
notably weird spots: such as this tick of

the border upward into Canada. Zoom in and
it gets stranger as the border isn't over

solid land but runs through a lake to cut
off a bit of Canada before diving back down
to the US.

This spot is home to about 100 Americans and
is a perfect example of how border irregularities
are born:

Back in 1783 when the victorious Americans
were negotiating with the British who controlled

what would one day be Canada, they needed
a map, and this map was the best available

at the time. While the East Coast looks pretty
good, the wester it goes the sparser it gets.

Under negotiation was the edge of what would
one day be Minnesota and Manitoba. But unfortunately,

that area was hidden underneath an inset on
the map, so the Americans and British were
bordering blind. Seriously.

They guessed that the border should start
from the northwestern part of this lake and

go in a horizontal line until it crossed the
Mississippi... somewhere.

But somewhere, turned out to be nowhere as
the mighty Mississippi stops short of that

line, which left the border vague until 35
years later when a second round of negotiations
established the aforementioned 49th parallel.

But there was still a problem as the lake
mentioned earlier was both higher, and less

circular than first though, putting its northwesterly
point here so the existing border had to jump

up to meet it and then drop straight down
to the 49th, awkwardly cutting off a bit of

Canada, before heading west across the remainder
of the continent.

Turns out you just can't draw a straight(-ish)
line for hundreds of miles without causing
a few more problems.

One of which was luckily spotted in advance:
Vancouver Island, which the 49th would have

sliced through, but both sides agreed that
would be dumb so the border swoops around
the island.

However, next door to Vancouver Island is
Point Roberts which went unnoticed as so today

the border blithey cuts across. It's a nice
little town, home to over 1,000 Americans,

but has only a primary school so its older
kids have to cross international borders four
times a day to go to school in their own state.

In a pleasing symetry, the East cost has the
exact opposite situation with a Canadian Island

whose only land route is a bridge to the United
States.

And these two aren't the only places where
each country contains a bit of the other:

there are several more, easily spotted in
sattelite photos by the no-touching zone.

Regardless of if the land in question is just
an uninhabited strip, in the middle of a lake,

in the middle of nowhere, the border between
these sister nations must remain clearly marked.

title: Canada & The United States: Bizarre Borders Part 2
